title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe one reason a country’s percentage of forest cover may change using ONE of the following:

Accept one of the following reasons for forest loss:

· Forests may be cleared for buildings (e.g., houses, businesses), or urban development, or recreational sites (e.g., golf courses), or industrial land use, or infrastructure projects (e.g., roads, powerlines, hydropower projects).

· Forests may be cleared for agriculture (e.g., farms, pastures) or mining.

· Environmental impacts (e.g., fires, floods, salinization, desertification, climate change, pests, disease, coastal erosion, drought, extreme heat, landslides, rising sea levels) may result in forest loss.

· Practices that are not sustainable allow forest loss due to logging for lumber, paper products, and/or energy use

· Geological forces (e.g., tsunamis, earthquakes, volcanoes) may destroy forests.

· Forest loss may occur in less developed countries as they industrialize, urbanize, and their economies grow.

Accept one of the following reasons for an increase in forest cover:

· Climate change (e.g., climatic shifts) may result in increasing forest cover (e.g., from increasing rainfall).

· Depopulation (e.g., of rural and/or urban areas) may allow a return of residential, industrial, or agricultural land to forest.

· Increasing quantity and/or size of parks or recreation areas may restore forests.

· Tree plantations (e.g., Christmas trees, rubber, eucalyptus) may be counted as forest cover.

· Governments, non-governmental groups, women’s groups, indigenous tribal organizations, and/or private citizens may implement forest restoration policies or practices that result in net afforestation.

· Forests may return as less land is needed for agriculture due to better crop yields.

Accept one of the following reasons for either an increase or decrease in forest cover:

· Inconsistencies in remote sensing data (e.g., gaps, misinterpretation) may lead to incorrect estimates of forest cover. Better data and/or improved interpretation may result in revised estimates that increase or decrease forest cover.

· A country’s land area may increase or decrease (e.g., Sudan losing area of South Sudan, land reclamation), resulting in loss or gain of forest cover.

· Political conflicts (e.g., wars) may result in gain (e.g., in no-go zones such as DMZs and areas with land mines) or loss (e.g., defoliation) of forest cover.

· Cultural practices that protect forests (e.g., protection of sacred groves in West Africa, protection of Indigenous sacred sites in Australia) may increase in scope, resulting in net gain of forest cover. The opposite can also happen, resulting in net loss of forest cover.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

The response must use data from the graph.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one reason for the global trend in forest cover over time using ONE of the following:

· Global forest cover has remained steady or has declined only very slightly because forest cover losses in some regions or countries have been offset (e.g., mitigated) by forest cover gains in other regions or countries.

· Global forest cover has remained steady or has declined only very slightly because destruction of forests (e.g., of rain forests) has been mitigated by regrowth of forests due to farm abandonment or to increasing urban afforestation.

· Global forest cover has remained steady or has declined only very slightly because forest cover losses have been offset by large-scale tree planting (e.g., reforestation) in certain areas (e.g., in China, in parts of Africa) and/or because of improved practices in forest management (e.g., using sustainability principles).

· Global forest cover has remained steady or has declined only very slightly because global warming (e.g., climate change) is allowing the tree line to change (e.g., forest can now grow at higher elevations and at higher latitudes, so alpine and Arctic tundra is shrinking), offsetting forest cover losses elsewhere.

· Global forest cover has remained steady or has declined only very slightly because less developed countries are still experiencing high rates of natural increase requiring increased resource and/or land use while developed countries have low or negative rates of natural increase enabling them to maintain current levels of forest cover.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

The response must include a statement or indication of a slight degree or no degree, a moderate degree, or a high or significant degree and an explanation.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain the degree to which Wallerstein’s world system theory explains changes in the pattern of forest cover since 1990 using ONE of the following:

· To a high degree or significant degree Wallerstein’s theory (world system theory) states that production and extraction (e.g., of resources such as timber) in peripheral and semi-peripheral countries support the core, which explains why countries such as Honduras, Brazil, and Indonesia are decreasing in forest cover and countries such as Germany, the US, and Japan are not.

· To a moderate degree Wallerstein’s theory may be correct in suggesting that the production and extraction forests may be more prominent in the peripheral and semiperipheral countries, but that does not necessarily impact the production and extraction of forest resources in core countries in the twenty-first century.

· To a slight or no degree Wallerstein’s theory does not account for overall world forest cover staying essentially the same due to non-economic factors (e.g., environmental factors such as climate change leading to forest advances in tundra regions).

· To a slight or no degree Wallerstein’s theory does not account for international agreements (such as REDD+, Payment for Ecosystems, Cash for Conservation) and efforts to protect forest cover in developing countries.

· To a slight or no degree Wallerstein’s theory does not account for forest cover conservation goals, policies or strategies a semiperipheral or peripheral country may have in place, but which are undermined by land use decisions made by private landowners.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain what the data shown on the graph imply about sources of energy in less developed countries using ONE of the following:

· Many people in less developed countries rely on firewood for energy (e.g., for heating and/or cooking) to an unsustainable extent (e.g., they have used trees for firewood and/or charcoal faster than forests can regrow).

· Many people in less developed countries lack access to or cannot afford non-wood sources of energy for their households (e.g., for heating and/or cooking), so they have degraded their forest resources for this purpose.

· More sustainable energy sources are not widely available due to a lack of available capital, a lack of infrastructure, and/or technicians to support these, and therefore people turn or continue to use wood as a source of energy.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain how the global demand for ONE of the following commodities may be driving local changes in forest cover using ONE of the reasons listed:

· Palm oil: Because there is high or growing global demand for palm oil used in foods and for other purposes (e.g., for cosmetics, soap, detergents, biofuel), forests in some countries (e.g., Indonesia, Honduras) are being destroyed and replaced with oil palm plantations.

· Soybeans: Because there is high or growing global demand for soy (e.g., from China) used in foods and for other purposes (e.g., oils, animal feed, industrial products), forests in some countries (e.g., in Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay) are being destroyed and replaced with soybean fields.

· Beef: Because there is high or growing global demand for beef used for food, forests in some regions (e.g., in the Amazon basin) are being destroyed and replaced with cattle pastures.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one consequence of forest cover change for environmental sustainability in more developed countries using ONE of the following:

· Environmental sustainability is affected as biodiversity and ecosystem services are reduced due to deforestation or increased due to afforestation and/or reforestation (e.g., habitat improvement).

· Environmental sustainability is diminished due to the climate change impacts of forest cover loss (e.g., less carbon storage and/or more carbon release (carbon dioxide), increased greenhouse gas emissions, conversion to industrial land uses) or may be increased (e.g., mitigate climate change, shift to alternative energy sources) due to the role of forests in carbon storage.

· Forest cover loss diminishes environmental sustainability by creating environmental justice concerns, because in some cases marginalized groups are disproportionately affected by forest loss (e.g., by resultant climate change, by loss of access to forest resources) or in some cases marginalized groups may support forest use as a method of economic development.

· Environmental sustainability is affected because loss of forest cover results in higher prices, increased demand, and/or reduced supply for housing and consumer products in more developed countries.

· Environmental sustainability is diminished because loss of forest cover may result in loss of soil and/or water quantity and quality (e.g., due to erosion, water pollution, runoff).

· Environmental sustainability is diminished when wildfires in more developed countries create airborne dust particles that pollute the atmosphere.

· Environmental sustainability is diminished when deforestation creates airborne dust particles due to fires set by humans or from soil erosion.
